climbs.name: Unknown Variation of V4 on West Overhang

content.description:
This is a variation to the V4 ("

Unknown V4

") starting on the low down pinch. It's easiest with a kneebar on the start hold immediately after pulling off the ground (it may be size-dependent, but it worked for me!). Continue into pocketed area, move up to small crimp, then shoot out right for a shoulder intensive move, from out from the jug at the top of

Slapper

. The grade is probably V4-5? Any suggestions or changes are welcome.

(If this route is the same as something else that I didn't see, feel free to delete it. I am rather new to the area's climbing.)
content.location:
Start on low pinch (same as "

Unknown V4

") of Mongoose Block.

climbs.name: Unknown V7 aka Slapper
climbs.fa: Dave Shearer and Preston Hopfensprenger in 1992 or 1993?

content.description: This is the hardest problem on this boulder that I know of. Start low on left sidepull and a really low, right pinch.
content.location:
This is on the Southwest corner of

Mongoose

.

content.description: Start on the loaf pinch down low. Fire up and out of the overhange. For some a knee bar is clutch.
content.location: This is on the West face of the Mongoose Boulder.

content.description:
Start standing on the right hand side of the south face. There are some obvious jugs up high, but ignore these, and start with both hands on a vertical rail. Layback this, with your right foot down low, and try and stick your left foot way up high onto a vertical edge. You have to be really precise with your left foot to stick this, and you start barndooring immediately if you don't get that foot right away.

Next, throw up to the big jugs, and figure out how to get your feet up, then climb up to the easy topout.

Yeah, it's pretty contrived, but it's fun movement nonetheless.
content.protection: A pad and maybe a spotter for the start.
content.location: This is on the right side of the south face.

content.description: Start standing immediately left of the chalked up southeast arete with an undercling for your right hand and a knob up high for your left (or match the undercling and throw up with your left for the first move). Paste your feet on, and throw up right to a good edge, then shuffle feet, and get a really high right foot in a small pocket (best to have a spotter here because a fall would be weird). Rock up onto this foot, throw up to a small knob with your left, then continue straight up for the topout.
content.protection: A pad and a spotter are recommended.
content.location: This is on the right side of the south face. It is as far right as you can go without being on the arete.

content.description:
I am posting this because I'd like to learn more about the FAist and if it might happen to have a name!

Sit start begins with a solid four-pad LH sloper and a thin, pinchable flake for the RH. Two moderate leftward LH bumps to slopey sidepulls will set you up for the crux: a final RH compression sloper, and a long LH throw to a diagonal jug / fatty, neutral edge.

The heelhook helps early; a slight counterclockwise spin on the rockover helps tremendously at the finish.

Precise hand placements and thumb catches make the problem.
content.location: Sit start begins on the northeast corner of the bloc. If you are standing and facing the leftmost edge of the north face downclimb, take a few more steps clockwise and you're there.

content.description: Start on lowest right hand pinch and left hand crimp flake further out from the slapper. Drop knee, hit the "Swiss Cheese" pocket/hold and top out on jugs. If anyone has additional information, including the actual name, please let me know!
content.location:
This is the center line, in between

The Slapper

and the

Unknown Undercling

, V4.

content.description:
Starting on the large jug at the southwest corner, make a large move up and right to another huge jug. Traverse into the steep flake system on the prow, and top out following laybacks or compression up the juggy flake. This si steep and fun for the grade on huge holds.

Please add any further info as known. This boulder has many beginner/moderate routes on it that are not listed currently.
content.protection: It has a huge, flat landing.
content.location: Stand start on the prow at the southwest corner of the block.

content.description:
Start as for

Unknown V7 aka Slapper

, and do the first move. Then bust right on a sloping rail to crimps on the main south face.  It is a surprisingly pure line and not too contrived for the Garden.

This may have been sent before, but I've never seen anyone working it in the years I've been bouldering at the Snake Pits.

Stand start at the large jug on the right side of the west face. Fire up and left to set of left-facing rails/flakes. Pull up onto the face using mostly jugs and large feet. It has great movement for the grade.

Please add any info including the FA and route name as known.
content.protection: There is a great landing. Use a pad or two.
content.location: It is on the West side of the prow at the southwest corner of the block.

content.description:
I'm submitting this route as a plea for help.  I can hardly get off the ground on this thing.

Perhaps someone who's sent it can fill in the beta?

As I understand it, grab the blocky slopers on the southeast arete, get your feet on somehow, and dyno for the top of the arete.
content.location: This is on the Southeast arete of Mongoose Block.

content.description: The line of least resistance, starting as far back in the cave as possible.  Grab a tufa-like thing with the right, and a rail sloper with the left.  Get through the two finger pocket and toss for the crimpy-jugs at the lip of the steepness.
content.location: In the middle of the overhanging west face of Mongoose Block, sit start.

content.description:
This is the obvious warm-up line near the middle of the south face. Starting on two left-facing sidepulls near shoulder height, get your feet pasted, and work your way up on positive crimps and small jugs. It has mostly good hands and feet.

If anything is known about the FA or route name, please let me know!
content.location: On the South Face (slab face), this starts on two left-facing sidepulls around shoulder height.

content.description:
Start low on the left side of the overhang on the large, undercling holds.  In the photo, you'd have your hands roughly matched where the guy's right hand is.  Stay low and move right through the start of the V4 into the start of

Slapper

.  Finish up with

Slapper

!

In my mind, this is the best problem at The Snakepits.

This is the no-hands start problem.  Start with a left heel in the big dish on the south-west overhang and PUSH with the right.  Do a full sit-up off the ground and reach bad crimps to bump to the giant bucket hold, then topout the V0.
content.location: It is on the Southwest corner of Mongoose Block.

climbs.name: Left Traverse into B*%€# Slap
climbs.fa: ? I am sure this has been done before

content.description: Start on far left underclings as for the Slapper Traverse, but keep on chugging along right into Bit€h Slap. This has sustained movement and is definitely harder (for me) than the Slapper Traverse.
content.protection: No pads. I used a yoga mat and my jacket.
content.location: From a big ol’ undercling, head right through sloper of B!+€# $lap.

content.description:
On the east overhang is the obvious line to the left of the moderate set of side-pulls and to the right of the arete/

Nose Lunge

line.

Start low, matched on a W-shaped crimp, pop right to a sloping ledge and then up on crimps.
content.protection: Throw a pad on the exposed rocks, and you should be fine.
content.location: The Mongoose Block is the first and largest boulder at The Snake Pits.  This problem is on the overhanging, east face.

content.description: Start hanging on your feet in the big dish. Flip yourself around using the sidepull slopers and the three finger crimp between your legs. You get bonus points if you do it in the dark. I’m sure someone had already done it.
content.location: Begin on the Southwest corner of Mongoose Block sightly to the right of the big rocks in the ground. The starting feet are in the big dish.

content.description:
Start on jugs on a large block. Paste your feet high and fire for large holds up and slightly right. Work your feet up to the top of the block, and follow huge jugs to the lip. This is potentially the easiest line on the boulder following jugs the whole way.

Please add any info as known as to FA or route name.
content.protection: Yet another great landing. Bring a pad.
content.location: It is on the left side of the large south face of the block.
